article-meta.aff: 1Condensed Matter Physics Laboratory, Department of Physics, Sree Narayana College, Kollam, Kerala, India
2Centre for Advanced Scientific Research and Rural Technology, Kollam, India
3Laboratory for Unconventional Electronics & Photonics, Department of Physics, National Institute Technology, Calicut, Kerala, India 673 601

author-notes.corresp: P Predeep, Laboratory for Unconventional Electronics & Photonics, Department of Physics, National Institute Technology, Calicut, Kerala 673 601, India. Email: ppredeep@gmail.com

abstract.p: An attempt has been made to develop intrinsically conducting nylon 6 films by iodine doping and investigate the doped material in terms of electrical, structural and optical characteristics. The electrical conduction increases with increasing iodine content as iodine forms charge transfer complexes with the polymer matrix and conductivity of the order of 10−3 Scm−1 is obtained with films that contained 200 wt% iodine. The extent of crystallinity reduced from 53% for pristine nylon 6 films to 47% for iodine doped nylon 6 films (200 wt% iodine). The band gap reduced from 5 eV to 2.40 eV for iodine doped nylon 6 films (200 wt% iodine). The melting point of the matrix polymer reduced from 220°C to approximately 200°C for iodine doped nylon 6 films (200 wt% iodine).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Conducting plastics have been proved to be promising materials for the fabrication of electronic devices as they can be doped to possess the electronic properties of a semiconductor to metallic regime. The conventional non-conjugated polymers such as polyesters, polyimides and polyamides have π-electrons, but they are all insulating as they lack extended conjugation. These non-conjugated organic polymers display a promising increase in electrical conductivity upon doping with appropriate electron acceptors or electron donors. They are soluble in many organic solvents and have the specific properties of plastics such as light weight and high mechanical strength. The ability of a polymer to form thin film from solution allows them to be deposited on many kinds of substrates, which may provide1 opportunities for many novel applications. Doping of polymers with protonic acids2 and investigations on polymer electrolytes3 focused on the enhancement of ionic conductivities at room temperature are important from both scientific and commercial point of view. The oxidants like halogens and Lewis acids have been used extensively to4–9 tailor the physical and chemical properties of polymers. A suitable dopant improves4–9 the charge carrier mobility of the polymer. It is known that iodine molecule possess acceptor properties and high electron afﬁnity and it captures a weakly localized π electron of polymer macromolecule, forming9,10 charge-transfer complexes, which improves the conducting behavior of polymers. Doping could be successfully done by the diffusion of oxidants from vapor, liquid or solid phase and is a relatively simple technique of modification of polymer properties. Sorption of polymer films in penetrant solution results in the separation of polymer segments11 before penetrant molecules, forming holes through which they can diffuse.

Polyamide nylon 6 used in this study belongs to the family of thermoplastics and is widely used in many engineering and technological applications in the pristine and doped forms because of its good mechanical properties and high thermal resistance. Doped conducting and semiconducting nylon with its proven advantages of plastic flexibility and ease of processabilty has all the potential to find applications in microelectronics, as electrical fuses, switches, sensors etc. Nylon 6 has the [-NH(CH2)5(CO)-] repeating group and is characterized by the presence of secondary amide groups NHCO in the polymer skeleton, and the hydrogen bonds formed between neighbouring chains strongly affects the mechanical properties. This polymeric material is semi crystalline with two well-established crystalline modifications,12 namely α phase and γ phase which can be transformed to each other in some cases. Various research groups have studied12–15 the effect of aqueous KI/I2 solution and iodine vapor16 on the structure and electrical conductivity properties of nylon-6. Earlier reports show that the electrical conductivity of the nylon 6- iodine adduct prepared at high temperatures increases to17 10−3 S cm−1. The iodine molecules or polyiodide ions interrupt the intermolecular hydrogen bonds, forming charge transfer complex with nylon 6 chains and there is considerable chain mobility in the nylon 6 – iodine complex during the transformation thereby enhancing the electrical conductivity. Doping of polymers using iodine under non-aqueous solution and the formation of charge transfer complexes has been reported by several authors. Kelkar and Gadre18 have investigated the complex formation using IR spectrum in iodine-doped PMMA at various concentrations of iodine using benzene as solvent. Wang et al.19 has studied the sorption of polyurethane and melamine-formaldehyde foams using iodine solution in toluene and hexanes. We have in our earlier studies reported5,6 development of very high intrinsic electric conductivity in other non-conjugated polymers like natural rubber (cis 1, 4-polyisoprene), acrylonitrile butadiene rubber (NBR) and styrene butadiene rubber (SBR) using iodine sorption in a non-aqueous medium using toluene.

In this contest, an effort has been made to prepare thin films of nylon 6 by solution casting technique and to study the effect of non-aqueous solution doping of iodine at room temperature for nylon 6 films on the electrical and optical performance. The structure of nylon 6 iodine complex films are studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. The optical, thermal and electric properties of nylon 6 films treated with iodine solution in toluene are discussed.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Polyamide, Nylon-6 rod of diameter 2.5 cm was purchased from Good Fellow materials, UK, and it was cut into small flakes for the experimental purpose. Iodine (Merck), toluene (Merck) and phenol (Merck) of analytical grade were purchased from local suppliers and used as received.

sec.title: Sample preparation
sec.p: Nylon 6 dissolves in phenol when the mixture is heated above 40°C and toluene is a non-solvent of nylon 6. However, in the composite solvent of phenol-toluene in the ratio 45:55, nylon 6 is found to dissolve even at room temperature at a much faster rate because20 the action of toluene is more effective in expanding the coil dimensions than phenol alone. On adding toluene to phenol, a number of potential contact sites are created20 and the combined contacts lead to enhanced solvation of polymer chain and its dissolution. Besides, the composite solvent is relatively economical and safe to use: 2.0 × 10−4 kg of nylon 6 is dissolved in 10 × 10−6 m3 composite solvent and the solution is magnetically stirred for 5–6 hours at room temperature to obtain a homogeneous solution. Flexible and free-standing nylon 6 films having micrometer (1–10 µm) thickness is then obtained on clean glass plates by solution casting and by slow evaporation of the solvent followed by drying for 1 h in a vacuum oven at about 120°C to remove residual solvent if any. For DC conductivity measurements, iodine doping was carried out by immersing the nylon 6 films in the iodine-toluene solution for different concentrations (0.04, 0.08, 0.16, 0.32 and 0.4 moles/l) at room temperature for 10 days. The films were then removed from the solution and washed with toluene to remove excess iodine. They were then drained and left to dry at room temperature. However, in order to study the effect of iodine more closely, doping was performed for different time periods (2 to 10 days) in iodine-toluene solution of concentration 0.4 moles/l. For all other measurements, an iodine solution of concentration 0.4 moles/l for 10 days was used for doping the films. All the samples were washed with toluene and left to dry. Sample mass was measured with an electric balance of minimum resolution of 0.1 mg and the relative increase in mass percentage, Δm%, were calculated: Δm% = [(mass of the complex sample) / (mass of the pristine nylon 6 film) –1] × 100%.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: The DC conductivity measurements of the doped films are made by the two probe technique using the Keithly 6514 Electrometer and Keithly 2400 source meter. As the thickness of the nylon 6 films increases after iodine doping, infrared spectra are taken with Nicolet 5700 FTIR Spectrometer using an attenuated total reflectance accessory (ATR). Uniform films of the samples placed on the ATR diamond crystal with suitable pressure (equal pressure for both pristine and doped films) are found to get optimal signals. XRD patterns are registered using CuKα radiation of wavelength λ = 1.5406 Å between a 2θ angle of 10° and 40°. This along with UV-visible absorption spectra taken on Cary 5000 at a scan rate of 600 nm/min in the wavelength range 200-900 nm provided data for evaluation of the optical constants such as band edge and optical band gap (both direct and indirect). Differential thermal analyses (DTA) are conducted based on ASTM E-537-98 using SDT-2960, TA Instruments Inc. at a heating rate of 10°C/min in nitrogen atmosphere.

sec.title: DC Conductivity
sec.p: Colour of the nylon 6 films are found to change from off-white to yellow, dark brown and finally to black with the increase in iodine content. The colour changes observed here indicates4–8 the formation of charge transfer complexes (CTCs) of iodine with the NHCO group of the polymer macromolecule because of the strong affinity of iodine to conjugate pair of π electrons at these sites. Earlier reports also suggest the interaction of iodine with nylon 6 at room temperature13,16,21 through the lone pair electrons of the amide group and formation of complex.

The current-voltage characteristic of nylon 6 iodine complex films measured at room temperature (Figure 1) also supports the observation based on color change. The complex formation results in the enhancement of conductivity. The I-V characteristic curve is a linear plot indicating the Ohmic characteristics of the charge transfer complexes. Figure 1.
I–V Characteristic of nylon 6 iodine complex films (iodine content 100 wt%).

Figure 2 shows the variation of the electrical conductivity as a function of percent iodine uptake on doping the nylon 6 films for 2–10 days in the iodine-toluene solution of concentration 0.4 moles/l. The DC conductivity is found to increase with the iodine content in the film which in turn increases with the period of doping. The conductivity is seen to increase by several orders of magnitude attaining a maximum value of 4.2 × 10−3 S cm−1 for films which contained 200 wt% iodine. It was also observed that as the concentration of the solution was increased (from 0.04 to 0.4 moles/l for a period of 10 days) the iodine content in the film improved which enhanced the conductivity of the film. In general, the conductivity increased with the iodine content in the film. Figure 2.
Variation of the electrical conductivity as a function of percent iodine uptake on doping the nylon 6 films for 2–10 days.

sec.title: FTIR analysis
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows the FTIR spectrum of pristine nylon 6 and nylon 6-iodine complex films. A comparative study of the spectra carried out on the pristine nylon 6 samples and doped nylon 6 iodine complex films (200 wt% iodine content) shows that significant changes are produced in the absorption bands of amide groups. The sharp and very strong band at 3291.7 cm−1 characteristic of9,22 the NH stretching in the spectrum of pristine nylon 6 has extended and decreased in intensity for doped film. The band at 3058.7 cm−1 assigned to9,22 the overtone of the amide II band has disappeared in the nylon 6 iodine complex films. These results indicate that hydrogen bonding is destroyed during the complex formation. The absorptions in the spectrum of pristine nylon 6 assigned to17 amide I (1633.3 cm−1) and amide II (1536.4 cm−1) bands have shifted to 1600 cm−1 and 1529 cm−1, respectively, and decreased in intensity, and amide III (1264 and 1199.6 cm−1) have considerably weakened or disappeared by the iodine treatment. The disappearance of amide III bands could be related to the reduction of the crystallinity12 of nylon 6 films when treated with iodine. Figure 3.
The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum of pristine nylon 6 and nylon 6-iodine complex films (iodine content 200 wt%).

The decrease in or disappearance of12 amide V and VI groups (688.3 and 575.5 cm−1) in the α-structure is a consequence of iodine treatment. The disappearance or weakening of amide bands of nylon 6 indicate17 that the structure around the amide group of nylon 6 has been profoundly changed by destruction of the α-form of nylon 6.

The absorptions assigned to22 the CH stretching of the CH2 groups around 2935 and 2867 cm−1 has shifted to 2925.8 and 2855.2 cm−1, respectively, indicating that iodine doping has caused changes in the ethylene sequences. The bands corresponding to CH2 groups12 are 1475.7, 1463.1, 1432 and 1414 cm−1. The band at 1432 cm−1 corresponding to12 the bending vibration of CH2 group next to the nitrogen which has lowest intensity for the pristine nylon 6 films shows an increase upon iodine treatment. This indicates12 the rotational deviation of the -CH2-CONH-CH2 group from the trans conformation to cis conformation. So one could say that in order to accommodate12,21 iodine that occupies a large amount of space, the amide groups are forced to move out of the plane by the CH2 groups which are next to the CO and NH groups resulting in a twist around the amide group. Further, in the iodized samples the 1475 and 1414 cm−1 bands do not appear but the 1432 and 1463 cm−1 bands do. This indicates that there is symmetrical deformation of the CH2 next to the nitrogen and other CH2 groups.

Moreover the bands at 1028.1, 958.8, 927.9 and 833.1 cm−1 corresponding to crystalline α-form have disappeared.12 The narrow and sharp characteristic band at12,23 979.5 cm−1 and less intense bands at 918 and 1000 cm−1 corresponding to the γ form have become prominent upon iodine treatment. As a result of the complex formation, the amide I absorption has red shifted to 1600 cm−1 and the NH stretching band has moved to higher wavelength region in the doped film suggesting9 that iodination occur on the carbonyl oxygen rather than on the amide group nitrogen. These changes in the iodized samples suggest that iodine penetrates into the nylon 6 films by breaking the hydrogen bridges forming complex with the amide group and produces distortion in the structure. High iodine concentration increases the amorphous content of the film thereby imparting high conductivity.

Iwamoto et al.24 and Maillo et al.12 have investigated the interactions of nylon 6 with water and have reported the changes observed in the amide I and II groups of nylon 6 due to its hydrophilic nature through FTIR spectroscopic studies. The iodine sorption in nylon 6 in this study is done in a non-aqueous medium toluene and so it is interesting to study the effect of toluene on nylon 6 films under the same conditions. Nylon 6 films were kept immersed in toluene for 10 days. They were then drained and left to dry at room temperature. The initial and final masses of the film were exactly the same. On observing the FTIR spectrum of the pristine nylon 6 samples and those treated with toluene, it is found that there is neither bond shifting nor change in intensity of bands taking place, indicating that no chemical interaction and depolymerization occur after exposing the nylon 6 films to toluene at room temperature (since the spectra of toluene treated nylon 6 films is identical with the spectra of pristine nylon 6 in Figure 3, it is not given).

sec.title: XRD analysis
sec.p:
The XRD patterns of pristine nylon-6 films and nylon 6-iodine complex films are shown in Figures 4 and 5, respectively. For the pristine nylon 6 films, two prominent peaks are located at about 2θ = 19.84 and 23.96°, which are assigned25 to (200) and (002)/ (202) reflections, respectively, which are the characteristic peaks of α phase. The α phase has a monoclinic structure and consists of fully extended planar zigzag chains. The adjacent antiparallel chains are linked by the hydrogen bonds of (002) plane. Figure 4.
X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of pristine nylon 6 film.
Figure 5.
X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of nylon 6 iodine complex film (iodine content 200 wt%).

After iodine treatment of the nylon 6 films which contained 200 wt% iodine an XRD peak appears around 2θ = 22.41°, which is almost consistent with the γ phase25 of the polymer corresponding mainly to the diffraction of (001) plane. However, XRD characterizations alone are not enough to determine the transition to γ phase. In conjunction with the investigations made using FTIR method one may suggest that the XRD peak at 22.41° probably indicates the twisted conformation in the ethylene sequences near the amide group which occur as a result of the complex formation of the polymer with iodine. The complex would form once the hydrogen bridges have been broken and a zig–zag type contraction of the chain must then be produced21 so that it can accommodate iodine that occupies a large amount of space. So, iodine treatment of nylon 6 films results in a transformation from α phase and could be considered as an intermediate stage to γ phase, which is obtained12 by the removal of the iodine with sodium thiosulfate. The change produced in the nylon 6 investigated by the diffraction methods could be attributed to15 the crystal phase of the complex.

sec.title: Determination of degree of crystallinity
sec.p: The degree of crystallinity of samples is quantitatively estimated. The degree of crystallinity is determined using equation (1): (1)χc=AcAc+Aa where χc refers to the degree of crystallinity; Ac refers to the areas of all the sharp crystalline peaks (2θ = 19.84 and 23.96° for pristine nylon 6 and 2θ = 22.41° for the doped film) and Aa refers to the amorphous area (remaining area under the diffractogram and base line, other than the area of crystalline peaks) on the X-ray diffractograms.

The degree of crystallinity of pristine nylon 6 film and nylon 6 iodine complex films is shown in Table 1. Pristine nylon 6 is found to have a higher degree of crystallinity than the doped films. Moreover, the XRD pattern of the complex films has much broader diffraction peaks of reduced intensity, signifying that the degree of crystallinity is considerably lower than that of pristine nylon 6 films and this agrees well with the results of the thermal studies given in the latter part of this study. The above result is strengthened by the findings of the research group of Jana et al. with polyurethane on reduced crystallinity26 owing to the non-covalent filler-matrix interactions. Table 1.
The degree of crystallinity of pristine nylon 6 film and nylon 6 iodine complex films.
Sample Degree of crystallinity χc %
Pristine nylon 6 53
Nylon 6 iodine 47

sec.title: UV-Vis absorption studies
sec.p:
Pristine and doped nylon 6 films are subjected to UV-visible absorption studies and the spectra are shown in Figure 6. It is clear from the spectra that the absorption increases on iodine doping with absorption edge extending towards near infrared region. This is essentially due to27 the formation of stronger charge transfer complexes upon heavy doping. This may be because of the8,28 the charge transfer between the double bond and the dopant resulting in conjugation of the NHCO group which improves the conducting behaviour of the polymer. The high optical density is due to the strong absorption of iodine, which is present in the polymer17 either in the form of I2 molecules or I3− and I5− ions. Iodine with its high electron affinity accepts an electron16 from the lone pair of the amide group and may form I− ions. This may further complex with I2 molecules to form I3− or I5− ions as the concentration of iodine increases. Presence of I3− and I5− ions in polymers is supported by the findings of Wang et al.19 with the help of Raman spectral studies in iodine doped polyurethane. The absorption coefﬁcient (α) is plotted against the photon energy (hν) for pristine and iodine-doped nylon 6 ﬁlms and is shown in Figure 7. Figure 6.
The UV-Vis spectra of (a) pristine nylon 6; (b) nylon 6 iodine complex (iodine content 200 wt%) films.
Figure 7.
Band gap of (a) pristine nylon 6; (b) nylon 6 iodine complex (iodine content 200 wt%) films.

The intercept of this plot on the photon energy axis gives the band gap (Eg) of the nylon 6. The band gap of nylon 6 iodine complex films with films which contained 200 wt% iodine is 2.40 eV and the value is found to decrease from 5.00 eV for the pristine film. The photon absorption in polymers obeys the Tauc’s relation3: (2)αhϑ=A(hϑ-Eopt)nforhv>Eopt0forhv<Eopt

Here α is the absorption coefﬁcient, hν the photon energy, A is a constant and the index n is the distribution of the density of states; n = 1/2 corresponds to the direct allowed transition energy gap and n = 2 represents the indirect allowed transition energy gap. The direct and indirect band gaps are determined from plots of (αhν)2 and (αhν)½ as a function of photon energy (hν) as shown in Figure 8 and 9, respectively. The intercept of these curves on the photon energy axis gives the direct and indirect band gaps. For pristine nylon 6 films the direct band gap lies at 5.05 eV, while for doped films, the value decreases to 2.47 eV. The indirect band gap lies at 4.92 eV for pristine nylon 6 films and for doped films, the value is found to be 2.21 eV. Figure 8.
Direct allowed transition energies of (a) pristine nylon 6; (b) nylon 6 iodine complex (iodine content 200 wt%) films.
Figure 9.
Indirect allowed transition energies of (a) pristine nylon 6; (b) nylon 6 iodine (iodine content 200 wt%) complex films.

It is clear from Table 2 that the direct and indirect band gaps show a decrease on doping with iodine. The reduction in the band gap due to iodine doping indicates27,28 the incorporation of iodine into the polymer chain, extending the density of states more into the visible and near IR region of the electromagnetic spectrum and, thereby, increasing conduction. Table 2.
Optical absorption edge, direct and indirect bandgaps of pristine nylon 6 and nylon 6 iodine complex films.
Absorption edge (eV) Optical bandgaps
Direct (eV) Indirect (eV)
Nylon 6 5.00 5.05 4.92
Nylon 6 Iodine 2.40 2.47 2.21

sec.title: Thermal studies
sec.p:
Doping with iodine generally changes the thermal properties29 of the polymer drastically. From the DTA curve (Figure 10(a)), the melting point of the pristine nylon 6 is found to be at about 220°C and the melting points of the doped films (Figure 10(b) and (c)) show a shift to lower temperatures as the iodine content increases. The melting point of the matrix polymer is reduced from 220°C to approximately 200°C for iodine doped nylon 6 films which contained 200 wt% iodine. The sharp endothermic peak and higher peak height in the DTA curve of pristine nylon 6 indicates that there is higher level or order present. From the DTA curves, it is understood that the height of the endothermic peaks is lowered for the doped films. Further, the absence or decrease in area of the exothermic peaks for the doped films leads to the assumption30 that the crystalline regions are destroyed or reduced by the formation of iodine adducts in the complex. This may be the probable reason for the significant reduction in the melting point of the complex films. Figure 10.
Differential thermal analyses (DTA) curves of (a) pristine nylon 6; (b) moderately and (c) heavily doped nylon 6 iodine complex films (exo-up).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Pristine and iodine doped nylon 6 films are synthesized. Electrical conductivity of nylon 6 films is enhanced by immersing the polymer films in non-aqueous iodine solution at room temperature. Iodine forms charge transfer complexes with the amide group of the polymer and the electrical conductivity increases to the order of 10−3 S cm−1 with films which contained 200 wt% iodine, which is a considerably large value for non-conjugated polymer-based materials. FTIR and UV-Vis studies reveal the formation of charge transfer complexes in the doped films. Optical properties like energy gap and band edge value shift to lower energies on doping with iodine. XRD and thermal studies show that crystallinity of nylon 6 reduces with iodine treatment. Iodine helps in improving the electrical conductivity of polymer by increasing the amorphous content of the polymer.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: One of the authors, P Predeep, is thankful to DST India for providing grant (No. SR/S2CMP-48/2006) to undertake this work.
